intro: Lappula xinjiangensis, commonly known as the Xinjiang lappula, is a flowering plant native to Central Asia, particularly found in regions of China, Kazakhstan, and Uzbekistan. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many economically important crops such as mustard and cabbage. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments. Its flowers are small and yellow, arranged in clusters, and it produces hairy, triangular seed pods. Lappula xinjiangensis is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and potential ecological significance in its native habitats.
